mods.abstract: Front showing the front of the Nashville Store Fixture Company at the intersection of Second Avenue and Church Street. Several of the windows in the building are open and a sign in one of the second-floor windows reads “fire”. The sign for the Nashville Paper Stock Co. is painted on the building to the right. Cars are parked along the street. The intersection has a streetlight and street signs marking Church Street and Second Avenue. The side of the building at 200-202 Second Avenue across the street is visible in the background, and one of the windows in the building reads "Fire Dept."

The C.T. Cheek & Son building, located at 184 Second Avenue, is a three-story brick commercial style building constructed in the 1890s. The bottom floor storefront consists of five bays. Brick pilasters extend to the flat roof with stone caps. Masonry on the building includes the limestone stringcourses on each floor and brick corbelling near the roofline and windows. The windows on the upper floors have arched transoms. J.P. Kirkpatrick purchased the property in 1898, and C.T. Cheek & Son, a wholesale grocery store, began occupying the building in 1901. The grocery business was founded by Christopher Cheek, with son Leslie Cheek later becoming his partner. Leslie Cheek purchased 100 acres to build the Cheekwood Estate, including the home and garden, after the sale of the family business. Other previous occupants have included B. Bagg & Son, Nashville Creamery Mfg. Co, Tennessee Glass Co., and Nashville Store Fixture Co. The Drouillard/Nashville Paper Stock Co. building, located at 182 Second Avenue, is a three-story brick Italianate style building constructed in the 1890's for James P. Drouillard. The bottom floor consists of two bays with the storefront featuring a decorative transom area and metal paneling. The building has a patterned cornice and cast-iron Corinthian columns. The four windows on the upper floors have limestone sills, keystones, limestone stone caps, and brick archways. Early Occupants of the building include the Kemker-Woolwine Candy and Cracker Co., John Deere Plow Co., and Parris Manufacturing Co. The Nashville Paper Stock Co. purchased the property in 1922 and operated it for many years. Previous addresses for the building include 8 South Market Street. The building at 200-202 Second Avenue was a three-story brick building built around 1890. The building feature textured brickwork, a stone foundation, arched windows, and cast-iron cornices. Occupants of the location over the years include Corbett Bros., Fuller-Cunningham Co., Odil & Co., and Goodies. The building was demolished and replaced with a parking lot.
